Award.AbstractNarration:
Xiaosong Li of the University of Washington is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop several time-dependent electronic structure methods in conjunction with rigorous analytical methods to address some specific and important systems of excited electronic dynamics interacting with an environment. The proposed research program builds on what the LI group has already accomplished in the field of first-principles electronic dynamics. The overall objective is to develop new methods that are able to address the time-dependent interactions of excited electronic dynamics with molecular degrees of freedom and solvent. The new methods allow Li and his coworkers to explore new, interesting phenomena with a level of accuracy and detail that meets the needs of cutting-edge experiments. Specifically, they plan to apply the new methods to investigate vibration-induced electron-hole pair relaxation, solvent-induced excited state decay and solvent-modulated excited state reaction pathways in organic and inorganic materials. The fundamental knowledge gained from these studies deepen the understanding of numerous related photophysical processes in organic and inorganic materials.

Excited electronic dynamics are ubiquitous in energy conversion, energy storage, and photocatalysis, as well as in information processing and storage. They are central to numerous futuristic, proposed technologies most notably in the area of photonics and spintronics. The knowledge gained from the proposed research has broad implications for each of these technologies by changing the way researchers understand excited state electronic structure/function relationships. This project could furthermore result in the development of new materials with novel photophysical properties for application in a variety of scientific contexts from fundamental research to energy conversion. The results of this project provide new fundamental insights into the interactions of excited electronic states and environments in chemistry and physics. The proposed research provides a mechanism for advanced interdisciplinary education and training in the areas of inorganic, theoretical, physical, and materials chemistry, in order to prepare participating undergraduate and graduate students for future careers in science, engineering, and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

Excited electronic dynamics are central to numerous emerging technological applications, most notably in the areas of photovoltaics, photonics and spintronics. The accurate prediction of excited state electronic dynamics in an experimentally relevant environment is crucial to attaining a detailed mechanistic understanding of the fundamental processes implicated in energy conversion, energy storage, and photocatalysis. Gaining this understanding demands that we also understand the influence of molecular vibrations and the solvent on excited electronic dynamics. The primary goal of this proposal is to develop several time-dependent electronic structure methods that are designed to address some specific and important systems of excited electronic dynamics interacting with its environment. This research aims to provide a deep fundamental understanding of the important parameters that govern the excited state electronic dynamics that will ultimately serve as the guiding principles needed for creating new materials by design.

Intellectual Merit

We apply a combination of time-dependent electronic structure theories and rigorous analytical methods to study excited state electronic dynamics. We develop several dynamical methods that allow for realistic and accurate simulations of photochemistry in solvent, charge transfer/injection at interfaces, and spin-dependent processes. Direct applications of the method developments include excitonic or electron-hole pair dynamics, and coherent charge-transfer dynamics in semiconductor quantum dot or organic materials. Highlights of the research outcome include:

(a) We develop a time-dependent non-equilibrium dielectric response in mixed quantum mechanics and continuum approaches that can address solvation effect on photochemical processes of solute. Applications of this work are not limited to the treatment of non-equilibrium solvation effects. Rather, we establish a framework for the general treatment of electronic dephasing and energy dissipation in first-principles electronic dynamics calculations.

(b) We formulate and develop a spin-dynamics method that can study the spin-dependent processes of many-electron systems in response to an external magnetic field. This method provides a unique opportunity to study chemical processes involving changes of spin angular momentum.

(c) We develop a direct ab initio (meta-)surface-hopping dynamics that allows simulations of rare non-adiabatic dynamical events. This approach accelerates the acquisition of temporal properties of systems exhibiting electronic non-adiabaticity in a systematic, reproducible fashion.

(d) We apply the new developments to simulate coherent exciton, exciton transfer and decay in silver nanowire. This work lays the theoretical groundwork for studying coherent multi-excitons, arising from coinciding resonant excitons of different electronic characteristics. The information gained from this work holds the potential for anisotropic nanoplasmonic applications.

Broader Impacts

This project results in the development of new materials with novel photophysical properties for application in a variety of scientific contexts from fundamental research to energy conversion. This research furthermore provides new fundamental insights into the interactions of excited electronic states and environments in chemistry and physics, and deepens our understanding of this important class of interactions. This project is transformative in that it yields new chemical strategies for controlling excited state dynamics and also provides new theoretical approaches to analyze the electronic structure origins of these dynamics.

The research also provides a mechanism for advanced interdisciplinary education and training in the areas of inorganic, theoretical, physical, and materials chemistries, in order to prepare participating students for future careers in science, engineering, and education. Students collaborate with experimental researchers at international universities, and participate in University of Washington’s interdisciplinary educational programs, providing them with invaluable exposure to other research experiences and scientific cultures. Special emphasis is placed on integration of research and education at the undergraduate and high school level through (a) extensive involvement of undergraduates in the scientific research, (b) incorporation of experiments and concepts from the proposed research into the University of Washington undergraduate physical chemistry curriculum, (c) collaboration with the University of Washington Amgen and NASA program to host undergraduate students from other institute as visiting scientists at University of Washington, (d) a “Science Boosters” program at the Roosevelt High School and the Ballard High School, and (e) “Chemistry Night for the Boy Scouts'” program at Bryant Elementary School.
